commitResults.messageTitle: Modify delete to await user confirmation
commitResults.messageBody:
Delete instantly removes contact if input is valid. To improve
user experience, request for confirmation before deleting.

Let's,
* Introduce state through a State interface and StateManager class
* Create a ConfirmationPendingResult class to represent
result returns of operations that require confirmation
* Create a ConfirmCommand
* Modify LogicManager to create ConfirmCommands instead of
normally parsing inputs through AddressBookParser if the app is
awaiting user confirmation.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update LogicManager constructor to take in State
commitResults.messageBody:
LogicManager instantiates its own StateManager in its constructor.

Providing state as an argument allows for greater testability
through dependency injection.

commitResults.messageTitle: Move confirm logic out of StateManager
commitResults.messageBody:
StateManager contains the code to execute upon command confirmation.

While this was done to keep state management tightly coupled
with the execution of the pending operation, this brings much
logic into State.

Extract logic in state into ConfirmCommand class. Instead of
handling state update in StateManager itself, expose a method
to update state and pass the updating of state as a callback
to ConfirmCommand.

This way, ConfirmCommand holds all related-logic and
state updating can still be controlled.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add more tests to cover StateManager
Address checkstyle errors in test files
Update javadoc styles to adhere to convention
Move ConfirmCommand creation logic to ABParser
commitResults.messageBody:
The logic to create a confirm command is in LogicManager.

To maintain the separation of concerns, move the logic
to create new confirmation commands to the AddressBookParser.

Also SLAP code.
Additionally extract out magic literals.
UC05 - Add confirm prompt to delete

There is no central way to access all commands in the application -
parser uses a large switch case to handle command matching.

Autocomplete requires a list of all command words. Creating and using
a central repository of commands instead of manually listing them
makes it easier to extend and manage the applications' commands.

Let's:
* Create a central command registry
* Create a CommandFactory interface
* Populate the registry with commands and factory methods
* Modify ABParser to use the central repository instead of
listing switch cases.

Add autocomplete hint feature by introducing Autocompletor class.
Use a trie to search for prefixes in order to keep response
time quick for lookups.

CommandRegistry is in commands package.

CommandRegistry is related to parsing and user-end
information. It would be more accurate to it under
the parser package.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update clear tests to reflect added confirm prompt

commitResults.messageBody:
Adding keyboard navigation by following a modal text-editor
philosophy allows us to quickly navigate while using the
application. Scrolling is done using k/l keys
which allows the user to quickly scroll without leaving the
home row, and is similar to vim bindings which will be
familiar to users.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add UI tests and include TestFX
commitResults.messageBody:
There is no mechanism to test UIs.

Let's add TestFX to the gradle configuration. TestFX allows
us to headlessly test UI components built with JavaFX.
JavaFX is introducing such a method, but is only out
in early access builds (see:
https://gluonhq.com/introducing-the-headless-platform-for-javafx/)

Let's
* Add TestFX as a test dependency, along with related
requirements
* Add UI tests for navigation operations

UI tests use hardcoded input values.

Refactor to use the bindings provided by MainWindow.

Errors occur with TestFX.

Remove the TestFX tests for now
to debug them in another branch
Add confirm prompt for clear
[US12] - Keyboard Navigation using vim-like modal input

commitResults.messageTitle: Update build.gradle test commands to be modular
commitResults.messageBody:
All tests run one `./gradlew test' is run.

Let's provide a mechanism to run solely non-gui tests
or gui tests by themselves. This allows us to modify
CI runs as UI testing is not desirable to be run every time,
as it takes a longer time.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix CI by using Virtual Desktop on Ubuntu
commitResults.messageBody:
TestFX does not work with CI Workflow, specifically
on ubuntu.

Install xvfb on ubuntu runner to launch a virtual desktop
to test UI in. Update build.gradle to not use headless
functionality when in CI environment, as it does not work.

commitResults.messageTitle: Clarify test cases,make input matching use KeyCode
commitResults.messageBody:
Test case naming is not consistent. Input matching in MainWindow
uses Strings. This is not ideal as many keyboard inputs do not
exactly match or have standard string definitions.

Make MainWindow use KeyCodes to match user input instead. This
simplifies matching by not requiring any conversion between String
and KeyCombination, and simplifies test cases by as direct
usage of KeyCodes in the robot's writing functionality is possible.
Add UI Tests with TestFX

commitResults.messageBody: Trigger save data for crud operation only

Updated t/ prefix no longer replaces and overwrites all the existing tags.
Instead, t/ prefix in edit in now used to add additional tags to a
contact. This allows for simpler adding of additional tags to a contact
without having to retype all existing current tags.

Added r/ prefix as a new CliSyntax. r/ will be used to specify removing
a specific tag when editing a contact.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove empty t/ and r/ prefix

commitResults.messageBody: UC02 - Update Edit Command

commitResults.messageTitle: Add alphabetical or recent order list
commitResults.messageBody:
Users can now use an optional flag -a to list all contacts by
alphabetical order

Users can now use an optional flag -r to list all contacts by recently
added order

If the user does not use the optional flag, it will list based on the
original order in the addressbook.json file

CRUD operations do not impact the original order of the
addressbook.
